item.question:
You want the system to shutdown at 17:00 this afternoon.
It is now 9:00. Which of the following commands will shutdown the system at 17:00 and sends out a warning message 20 minutes prior to shutting down?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which file is created or updated when you execute the command <font face="monospace">ldconfig</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command displays the shared libraries an executable uses?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are logged in as root, and want to execute the command ls as user fordp. You do not know his password.
How would you do this?
item.choice: It is not possible, because you do not know his password.
item.hint: You are root and as the root user you can become any user without providing a password.

item.question:
Consider the above command and its permissions.
Which of the following descriptions are correct?
Choose all that apply.
item.choice: The command cannot be executed by root as it has not the x-permission set for the user.
The command will remain in memory because it has the s-permission set which means sticky.
The command will run with root-privileges even when started by a regular user.
The command allows all users to change any password as the command will run with root-privileges
item.correct_answer: The command will run with root-privileges even when started by a regular user.
item.hint: Notice the <font face="monospace">s</font> permission for the user. The <font face="monospace">s</font> means the setuid permission is set. It is a lowercase <font face="monospace">s</font> which means the file also has execute permission set for the user <font face="monospace">root</font>.

item.question:
You received an ASCII file from a good friend of yours who uses the windows OS.
You notice that you see a lot of CR-LF line endings in the file.
How can you remove the CR part from the file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following Linux commands can be used to create backups of filesystems and directories?
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: Although the question asks you to select all correct answers it does not mean there are multiple correct answers. However, if there are more than one correct answers you will need to provide them all to get points for this question.

item.question:
Which of the following commands can you use to get the documentation for a specific program?
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: Although the question asks you to select all correct answers it does not mean there are multiple correct answers. However, if there are more than one correct answers you will need to provide them all to get points for this question.

item.question:
What would be the correct command to remove the package atop completely from a Debian system?
Select two.
item.hint: By default removing a package under Debian will not remove the configuration files as well.

item.question:
Suppose that you know that a task deals with the general concept monitoring, but you are not certain what commands are available for monitoring.
Which of the following Linux command lines would be the BEST first step in finding out about available tools?
item.hint: Personally you may find more than one answer correct. The question asks for a first step so you should select a single answer.

item.question:
You downloaded a nice piece of software in RPM format.
You are running Debian Linux.
Which of the following would help you to install it on your system?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following will copy the text-file file1 to file2?
Choose all correct answers.
item.hint: Note that the question is about copying a TEXT file and not a binary file.

item.question:
You are editing the file foo with vi.
You want to save the changes with '[ESC]:w', but vi complains you do not have sufficient rights.
Therefore, you want to check the permissions on that file.
How do you manage this without leaving vi?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands will display the file /etc/hosts on standard output with all instances of 1 replaced by 2?.
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
With the command __________ you can display a file in octal format.
Provide only the name of the command.
item.hint: The question asks for only the commandname so providing the path as well, even if correct, is considered a wrong answer.

item.question:
You are searching for the file ring which is owned by user frodo.
Assuming the file is on a mounted filesystem and permissions are sufficient,
which command most likely will display its full path name?
item.hint: The question mentions a mounted filesystem and asks you the most likely command that will find the file. This kind of information is essential to answer this question correctly. If this was not added more answers would be correct. Try to remember the difference between find and locate. That should provide you with enough clues to answer the question correctly.

item.question: What will the above command do?
item.choice: Write the directory listing to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files and errors to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font> and discard errors
item.correct_answer: Write all directories and files and errors to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When you wish to install a new application you downloaded from the internet what would be a good location on the filesystem according to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
Assume that you want other users to be able to use the application as well.
item.hint: The question mentions a new application downloaded from the internet. It does not mention the format of the application, so you may assume that it is not a package from your linux distribution.

item.question: Which command would give you a listing of the contents of a tar archive?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which RPM command displays all files belonging to package <font face="monospace">foo</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.exhibit:
$ chmod "mode" foo
$ ls -l foo
-rwsr-xr-- 1 guru1 course 42 Sep 6 14:46 foo
item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
Select the possible value for mode that caused the file foo to get the above permissions:
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to use shared libraries that are in /home/guru1/mylibs (which is not in the standard library search path).
What is the appropriate command to use these libraries.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command that will not shutdown the system but will send the warning message that the system will shutdown.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are using disk quota on your system.
With the command ___________ (full path name) you can see disk quota details.
item.hint: The question requires you yo provide the complete path to the command. For instance <font face="monospace">/bin/ls</font>. If you only provide the commandname the answer will be wrong. Beware of typos. If multiple commands provide the asked information provide only one of these commands as answer.

item.question: Which of the following commandlines allows you to cancel a previous issued <font face="monospace">shutdown</font> command?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
At the commandline you set a variable's value with the command export MYVAR=hello.
Afterwards you execute the above script.
When the script finishes you type the command echo $MYVAR.
What would be the output of the last command you executed?
item.hint: The script is started by a child proces. Therefore the variable <font face="monospace">MYVAR</font> in the script is set in the child proces and will be lost when the script finishes.

item.question: If you want to change the default runlevel on a RedHat system to start a graphical login which line would you use in <font face="monospace">/etc/inittab</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.exhibit:
kapp: error while loading shared libraries: libkapp.so.1:
cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
item.question:
You downloaded some software and installed it under /usr/local.
When you run the command it fails with the above error message.
You located the file in /usr/local/lib.
How would you proceed to solve this issue permanently?
item.choice: Add <font face="monospace">/usr/local/lib/</font> to the variable <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font>.
Move the file <font face="monospace">libkapp.so.1</font> to <font face="monospace">/usr/lib</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.exhibit:
$ cat input.txt
10 1 monkey
9 10 donkey
1 2 mule
201 9 bird
87 10 dog

$ COMMAND
10 1 monkey
1 2 mule
201 9 bird
87 10 dog
9 10 donkey
item.question:
In above exhibit first the original text is shown and second the output is shown from COMMAND.
Which of the following commandlines can be used in place of COMMAND to generate the shown output?
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: The order in which the file is sorted is not numerically but alphabetically.

item.question: Which condition(s) must be true if two directories each require their own quotum for filesystem usage?
item.choice: They must exist on Ext3 partitions
The directories must have the setgid permission set.
They must be on different partitions
They must be mounted by the root user
item.correct_answer: They must be on different partitions

item.question: Which of the following commands can be used to create a tar archive file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: On a Debian system, which command will list all installed packages?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You started the program rups in the background and you notice it consumes a lot of resources.
Which of the following commands can you use to make the command you just started use less CPU resources?
item.hint: The question is about changing the priority of a RUNNING proces. Changing the priority is done by changing the nice value of the proces. A lower value means less nice, a higher value means the proces is nicer to other processes regarding CPU resources.

item.question:
You are looking for the string MyString (not mystring) in the file foo.
Which of the following commands can you use?
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands would return all lines that contains text between brackets (i.e. [...])?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">grep</font> uses regular expression syntax to specify the match filter. Brackets allow you to specify a set of characters that may occur at a single position. The caret inside brackets means you do not want the specified characters to match at that position. The dot (<font face="monospace">.</font>) means a single random character, but within brackets means a literal dot. The backslash escapes the next character which means it loses it special meaning, if any, and will be considered literally.

item.question: Which filesystems are mounted using <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font> when you issue the command <font face="monospace">mount -a</font>?
item.choice: All filesystems except those on removable media.
None, you forgot to specify a device-file and mount location.
All filesystems except those that have <font face="monospace">noauto</font> specified as mount-option.
item.correct_answer: All filesystems except those that have <font face="monospace">noauto</font> specified as mount-option.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
If your system is running in runlevel 2 what best describes this runlevel on
a RedHat system?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to repeat the last command you executed.
How would you do this?
item.hint: When the shell version is not stated explicitly always assume the question is about Bash.

item.question:
To list the PIDs of running applications which commands can NOT be used?
(Select all correct answers)
item.hint: Beware that sometimes the question asks for the opposite. In this case commands that DO NOT list the PIDs.

item.exhibit:
$ touch nicefile
$ ls -l nicefile
-rw-r--r-- 1 guru0 cursus 0 Sep 28 13:57 nicefile
item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
What is the most probable value of the umask set for user guru0?
item.hint: With <font face="monospace">umask</font> you can specify the mask numerically or symbolically. When the mask is in numeric form it specifies what is blocked.

item.question:
You need to display all files in the current directory that start with at and end with a g.
Choose the best answer.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can be used to determine the available space on all mounted partitions?

item.question:
Which of the following entries from the file /etc/fstab are correct?
Choose all answers that are correct.
item.hint: Some directories are by default connected to special in-memory filesystems which should not be exported.

item.question: What is the default signal the <font face="monospace">kill</font> command sends to a process when the signal is not specified?

item.question:
You added a new shared library to the system, so you want to update ld.so.cache.
Which command do you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The command '<font face="monospace">echo $?</font>' will give you what information?
item.choice: The process id of the current shell.
The process id of last executed command.
The exit status of the last executed background command.
The exit status of the last executed foreground command.
item.correct_answer: The exit status of the last executed foreground command.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which run level can be used as administration mode?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the result of the above command?
item.choice: You will get the shell secondary prompt
The text echo ATcomputing will be printed
item.correct_answer: You will get the shell secondary prompt
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command to <font face="monospace">fsck</font> on the next reboot?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to see detailed information of the installed package samba.
Which RPM command would provide you this information?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a directory?
item.choice: all files created in the directory will belong to the same group as the directory.
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner
it can be used to temporarily lock the directory
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.correct_answer: files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which commands would check the integrity of an ext2 filesystem?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You enabled quota support for users on the filesystem mounted on /extra.
Which file holds the current quotas for users?
item.hint: The quota system keeps its administration on the filesystem itself. Knowing that the question is about user quota support, you should be able to pick the correct answer.

item.question: The root filesystem resides on device <font face="monospace">/dev/sda2</font>. What is the corresponding name for this device in GRUB's configuration file at the line '<font face="monospace">root (</font>_______<font face="monospace">)</font>'? (Assume GRUB 1 is used)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will show you a list of your previously executed commands?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following is considered the best order for specifying a command at the commandline in Bash?
item.hint: Although multiple choices provide a correct commandline the question asks for the best order. This means the most complete correct description.

item.question:
A process with process id 42 is behaving badly.
You wish to terminate it with a command.
What is the appropriate command that sends the terminate (TERM) signal to the process?
item.hint: Read the question and answers very carefully. At first glance you may think multiple answers are correct, but only one really is correct.

item.question:
You want to move all directories and ONLY directories in you current working directory that start with test to the directory testing.
Which of the following commands would be best to perform this task?
item.hint: The question states you want to MOVE the directories which means you can eliminate one answer immediately. The question also states you want to move ONLY directories which eliminates another answer. Now you are left with two possible answers and it comes down to knowing if the command requires an option or not.

item.question:
You have created a script called /etc/init.d/cleanup. Which inittab entry
will run this once in runlevel 4 without waiting for completion?
item.hint: The question does NOT say ONLY in runlevel 4.
